content.title: Brachiobasilic Arteriovenous Fistula
content.definition: A two-stage or one-stage surgical creation of arteriovenous fistula using the basilic vein, which requires transposition to a superficial location due to its deep medial position.

clinical_features.salvage: Last autogenous option before AV graft

clinical_features.stage_1: Create brachial artery to basilic vein fistula in situ
clinical_features.stage_2: Elevate and transpose basilic vein to superficial tunnel
clinical_features.advantages: Higher maturation rates, easier second stage with arterialized vein

clinical_features.technique: Create fistula and transpose vein in single operation
clinical_features.disadvantages: Handling thin-walled vein, potentially higher failure

clinical_features.mobilization: Extensive mobilization from axilla to elbow
clinical_features.tunnel: Create lateral or anterolateral subcutaneous tunnel

clinical_features.advantages: Preserves basilic vein that is often well-preserved
clinical_features.complications: Steal, hematoma, wound complications higher than cephalic fistulas
